awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Decoupled Execution Paradigm for Data-Intensive High-End Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
/O on High-End Computing (HEC) machines is increasingly becoming the killing performance bottleneck. However, conventional execution paradigms for HEC are computing-centric and have inherent limitations in addressing critical I/O issues of data-intensive applications. There is a great need for developing unconventional execution paradigms to meet the growing I/O demand of high-end computing.

In this project, the PIs propose a decoupled execution paradigm (DEP) to address I/O bottleneck issues. DEP is the first paradigm enabling users to identify and handle data-intensive operations separately. The objective of the proposed research is three-fold: 1) understanding the execution paradigm requirement from the data-centric point of view, 2) studying the feasibility of the proposed decoupled execution paradigm, and 3) providing a partially implemented prototyping of DEP and its associated system design to support the first two objectives. Several technical hurdles have been identified, which include system architecture, programming model, and runtime system. Solutions are proposed and detailed plans are provided to evaluate the newly proposed decoupled execution paradigm.

por.por_cntn:
This project enables three institutions, Illinois Institute of Technology, Texas Tech University, and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, to collaborate together and conduct cutting-edge research and development in order to address the critical data-access bottleneck issue in high-end scientific computing. This project supported and nurtured 8 Ph.D. students and a large number of Master and undergraduate students, which has a clear impact in training and developing the future workforce, as well as in contributing new knowledge discovery and technology development for the society.

More specifically, this project develops the methodologies of a new “decoupled execution paradigm” for high-end scientific computing. For the first time, the decoupled execution paradigm enables the identification and handling of data-intensive operations (operations that manipulate a large amount of data and spend the majority of time in data accesses) separately from compute-intensive operations (operations that spend the majority of time in CPU cores) for the best overall efficiency and productivity in scientific simulations and applications. This project has developed advanced understandings of the execution paradigm requirement from a data-centric point of view and built critical solutions. The research and development activities conducted throughout this project have generated over 20 high-quality publications, and several publications received awards. For example, one paper received the Best Paper Award at the 14th IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications, and one paper received the Best Paper Nomination at the 11th IEEE International Conference on Networking, Architecture, and Storage. These publications have well disseminated the research findings and new knowledge and technology developed.  

This research created advanced solutions and technologies that can have direct impact on improving the efficiency of data accesses for scientific computing simulations and applications. High-end computing is a major strategic tool for science, engineering, and industry. Many scientific computing simulations and applications in critical areas of science and technology, such as nanotechnology, astrophysics, climate, computational chemistry, computational biology, and high-energy physics, have become highly data intensive. The investigations carried out in this project can advance a broad range of fields and disciplines, and the new methodologies and techniques developed can increase the productivity of scientific computing simulations and applications in many disciplines. The research results of this project can also have a profound impact on hardware and software stack solutions for high-end computing that are of national interests and importance. Throughout this project, the principal investigators have mentored and trained 8 Ph.D. students and a large number of Master graduate and undergraduate students. These students were exposed to the most advanced technologies and the latest research results in storage systems, high-end computing, and parallel computing throughout this project. The experience they gain in this project is directly related to their research, Ph.D. dissertation or Master thesis or undergraduate research, and will be relevant to their future career, whether it is academic or industrial. In particular, one Ph.D. student graduated in 2014 and joined Bloomberg as a technical staff; two Ph.D. students graduated in 2015 and joined Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Texas Tech University as research staff members, respectively. One Ph.D. student continues advanced education at Georgia Tech, and four other Ph.D. students are close to graduation. Undergraduate students who received training via this project have either continued for advanced graduate education or landed a suitable job with companies like IBM, AT&T, National Instruments, etc., which uses their research experience gained through this project too.
